title: 109_hr3552
content: The Act may be cited as the Coastal Barrier Resources Reauthorization Act of 2005. Digital Mapping Pilot Project Finalization. The Secretary of the Interior must submit a report on digital maps of the John H. Chafee Coastal Barrier Resources System units within 2 years of the Act's enactment. The report must be prepared in consultation with Governors of relevant states and include public comments. The report required under subsection (a) shall contain final recommended digital maps, adoption recommendations by Congress, summaries of comments received, updates on protocols and findings, and analysis of benefits of utilizing digital mapping technology for System units and protected areas. Authorization of $500,000 for implementation is provided. The Secretary is appropriated $500,000 for fiscal years 2006 through 2007 to carry out the section. DIGITAL MAPPING PROJECT for the remaining John H. Chafee Coastal Barrier Resources System units and protected areas. The Secretary of the Interior will create digital versions of all John H. Chafee Coastal Barrier Resources System maps, including protected areas not covered in previous projects. Existing spatial data will be utilized, and other agencies may provide additional data. The Secretary of the Interior will create digital versions of all John H. Chafee Coastal Barrier Resources System maps, utilizing existing spatial data. Federal agencies must provide data upon request, while state and local agencies are encouraged to do so. If necessary data is missing, an agreement will be made with the US Fish and Wildlife Service and the US Geological Survey. The United States Geological Survey will obtain and provide data to the Director of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service in compliance with data standards. A report must be submitted by the Secretary of the Interior within 5 years after the transmittal of the previous report. The Secretary will submit a report to the Senate and House committees regarding digital maps created under this section. The report will be prepared in consultation with Governors of relevant states and will include information on any differences between boundary lines on digital maps and original maps. The Secretary will submit a report to Congress summarizing comments on digital maps, recommending their adoption, suggesting expansion of protected areas, and providing updates on their implementation. The report to Congress will include recommendations for making all System unit and protected area maps available in digital format, as well as integrating digital boundaries into planning tools at various levels of government. SEC. 4. GRANT PROGRAM FOR COMPREHENSIVE INVENTORY AND ASSESSMENT OF UNDEVELOPED COASTAL BARRIERS. The Secretary of Interior will establish a grant program for identifying, assessing, and recommending additional eligible coastal barriers along the Atlantic and Gulf coasts and the Great Lakes shore areas. States receiving grants must conduct a comprehensive inventory of undeveloped coastal barriers. States receiving grants must conduct a comprehensive inventory of undeveloped coastal barriers that meet specific criteria, including being undeveloped coastal barriers, not designated as a protected area, consisting of at least five acres above mean high tide, and having a minimum of approximately one-quarter mile of shoreline on the unprotected side. Each state must prepare and submit a report to the Secretary based on the inventory. Section 10 of the Coastal Barrier Resources Act authorizes $3,000,000 annually from 2006 to 2010 for the Secretary to implement the Act.
